To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

14 Maij
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.48r
May it please yo
r
good L. to
e effect of my
last, w
ch
I writte to yo
r
L.
e 5 of this
moneth, there is order taken,
at w
t
in these two
daies
e greatest part of
e troupes, whiche are
to be imploied in this sommer service, shall
meete together at
e Vaert, w
ch
is a Fare by
Utrecht.
For w
ch
cause
Count Maurice
is gone
already towardes Utrecht, purposing pre-
ently upon
e assembly of
e forces, to marche
into
e filde. There are w
t
him in company
e
L. Burgh
, and his brother
S
r
John Burgh
, w
t
a 150 souldiers, w
ch
are specially chosen out
of every Enseigne of
e
Brille.
For
e
better direction of
e affaires of
e warre, it
is also resolved
at
e
Councel of State
shall
reside w
t
e Camp: but
e
General states
continewe alwaies at
e Hage. For my self
I am purposed, as occasions falle out, and as
I finde most behoofull for geving notice
to her Hig
nes
of suche actions as passe, to remaine
for
e most at
e Campe, and sometimes at
e
Hage, for
e answear and poursuit of suche
causes and letters, as her
Ma
tie
may send.
S
r
Francis Vere
being nowe at
Duisbourgh
is appointed as this night, to surprise
e fort
before
Zutphen,
w
ch
is supposed to be but
weakely garded. Failing of his purpose, he
hath order to streicten all
e passages
at laid
to Zutphen and
Deventer,
and thereafter
as they finde that those townes may be distressed,
their siege shall be planted before
e one or
e other.
We are daily advertised of
e Enemies
fol.48v
preparations of boates, bridges and other need-
full provision, for
e passage of rivers. But we
can not come to notice, w
at
is meant to be exploited.
Only this day we have intelligence, by a burger
of
Nieumeghen,
at
e towne having often and
grievously complained to
e
D. of Parma
, that
unles they may be freed of
at fort, w
ch
was built
before the towne, by
e states
e last sommer, by
w
ch
they finde themselves greatly dammified,
ei
shall be forced, er be long, to accord w
t
e states:
the Duke therupon hath promised to be shortly w
t
them, and to accomplishe their desire. W
ch
is all
as yet
at we can learne, of any part of his de-
signes. There is nowe accorded by
e states a contribution of 10000
li
ster
l
towardes
e levie in
Germany:
and there is order also tak-
ken,
at it shall be presently paied. There
are two of
e shippes of this contrey escaped out
of
Spaine
by an adventure somwhat strange, w
ch
I
thought not unworthy to be reported to yo
r
L.
They were staied at
Caliz
in
Andaluzia,
by
commission from
e
King,
and were freighted w
t
souldiers, to watche in
e streictes for certaine En-
glishe shippes, w
ch
were expected from
e Levant.
One of them was of a 100 last, and
e other of 80
and eche of them manned w
t
towardes 30 mar-
iners of this contrey. The masters grieving to
be letted of their course and traffique, agreed by
secret compact, to observe an opportunitie, when
e souldiers were under hatches, and to shutte them
fast. Whiche they did very happely, and
upon
meeting by chance, at
e same time, w
t
a shippe of
Breme,
forced her to take all
e souldiers a borde,
w
ch
they caused to come fourthe from under
e hatches
fol.49r
by one and one, and were all sett a land by
e
shippe of Breme. The other two turned home-
wardes, and are arrived in safety at
Amster-
dame
: w
t
6 brasse peeces of artillerie in eche
shippe, and
e provision of victualles, pouder, and
other necessary furniture, w
ch
was putte in to serve
e turne, for w
ch
they were taken by
e King.
And thus for want of other mater I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. May 14
1591
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley.
